comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content:
Greetings from Montreal!
I love these photos and have been following these posted pictures from the State Library of NSW for quite a time. I had the good fortune to visit Sydney and environs a few years ago for 5 weeks, and was enchanted with your country. I left with a fascination for the history of Australia, and a respect for the hardships that people endured. Thanks for posting these photographs, not only to delight me, but to preserve the rich history of NSW.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Thank you La Belle! I'm glad you had a good time in Sydney - don't forget to visit the Library in person next time!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Nerval: "Why should a lobster be any more ridiculous than a dog? ...or a cat, or a gazelle, or a lion, or any other animal that one chooses to take for a walk? I have a liking for lobsters. They are peaceful, serious creatures. They know the secrets of the sea, they don't bark, and they don't gnaw upon one's monadic privacy like dogs do. And Goethe had an aversion to dogs, and he wasn't mad." - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gérard_de_Nerval#Pet_lobster

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: I stand corrected. And would love to return to walk among the ducks and lobsters. Am I allowed to bring a well-behaved lobster on a lead when I visit the Library? It's lobster season here in Canada, and this may be a new niche tourist market.
